hints.content: Start by understanding the definition of a 'good' array. A good array is a permutation of base[n], which includes numbers from 1 to n-1 exactly once and two occurrences of n.
Identify the maximum number in the array. This number will be your candidate for n. Remember, for an array to be good, the maximum number must appear exactly twice.
Check the length of the input array. For it to be a permutation of base[n], the length of the input array should be n + 1 (since base[n] has n + 1 elements).
If the maximum number is n, ensure that the array contains all integers from 1 to n-1 exactly once. You can use a set to help track these numbers.
Count the occurrences of the maximum number in the array. If it appears twice, that's a good sign, but you also need to check the other numbers.
Use a loop to check if every number from 1 to n-1 is present in the array. If any number is missing, the array cannot be good.
Consider edge cases where the array length is 1 or 2. For example, an array [1, 1] is good, while [1] is not.
You may want to use a frequency counter (like a dictionary) to count how many times each number appears. This can simplify checking for duplicates and missing numbers.
Before concluding, ensure that the counts of all numbers from 1 to n-1 are exactly 1 and the count of n is exactly 2. This is crucial for the array to be a valid permutation.
Finally, combine all your checks: the length of the array, the presence of numbers from 1 to n-1, and the counts of n. If all conditions are satisfied, return true; otherwise, return false.

questionNotes: The maximum number in the array determines the candidate n.
The length of the array must be n + 1.
Numbers from 1 to n-1 must be present exactly once.
The maximum number n must appear exactly twice.
Edge cases include very small arrays, such as [1] or [1, 1].
